steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Latin A Week 11, Day 1. Before new ideas, let’s recall last week. What does the verb *sum* mean?
Right — *sum* means 'I am.' Chant the whole family: *sum, es, est / sumus, estis, sunt.*
Excellent! Now we shift from being to doing. Meet our first big verb family — *–āre* verbs, called First Conjugation.
Our five new verbs are: *amō* (I love), *portō* (I carry), *laudō* (I praise), *vocō* (I call), *parō* (I prepare). Repeat each after me.
Chant with gestures –ō (hand to heart), –s (point to partner), –t (hand forward), –mus (hands together), –tis (gesture to group), –nt (arms wide).
Apply to *amō*: amō, amās, amat, amāmus, amātis, amant. Chant together!
Translate together: *Puella amat rosam.* Who is the subject? What is the verb? The object?
Yes — 'The girl loves the rose.' Try this: *Puer portat aquam.*
Correct — 'The boy carries the water.' Our faith phrase this week is *Deus nos amat – God loves us.* Say it three times with care.
Quick check: I love = am__, you love = am__, we love = am__.
Good work! Diligence means small careful steps repeated faithfully. See you tomorrow for Day 2 to strengthen speed and accuracy.
